prospects.name: Balance Training for Runners
prospects.description: Balance training is crucial to improve your running performance, and yoga is a fantastic way to hone your skills. In this sequence, we practice a number of one-legged standing, dynamic poses to improve your balance and proprioception (your sense of where your body is in space). These poses are also great for building strength and flexibility in the hips.

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Mobilize Your Body
prospects.description:
In this video, we focus on mobilizing the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, ankles, and toes to enhance overall mobility throughout the body. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or evening to alleviate stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase mobility in the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, and ankles.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Screaming Toe
- Wrist Circles
- Elbow Circles
- Shoulder Circles
- Neck Circles
- Thunderbolt
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Thoracic Spine Circles
- Seated Twists
- Hip Circles
- Squat Twists
- Standing Forward Bends
- Reclining Hip Circles
- Windscreen Wipers
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Knees-To-Chest

prospects.name: Hip Openers
prospects.description: Seeing gains from the _Hip Openers_ session? This series will build on those gains, further loosening overworked and inflexible muscles in and around the hip joints.

prospects.name: Scapular Stability
prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Chest Opener
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to open up the chest and improve mobility in the spine and shoulders. It includes stretches for the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, hamstrings, and calves. The poses are particularly effective for alleviating pain between the shoulder blades. This sequence is ideal as a post-workout routine, especially after working the chest or engaging in activities that involve a closed-chest posture. It is also beneficial after a day spent hunched over a computer.

​

The objectives are to open up the chest, enhance mobility in the spine and shoulders, stretch the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, calves, and hamstrings, and help alleviate pain between the shoulders.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Cat–Cow with Forearm Stretch
- Puppy
- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Downward Dog
- Low Lunge with Chest Opener
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Camel
- Wide-Knee Child’s Pose
- Reclining Butterfly (on blocks)

prospects.name: Hip Mobility Flow for Runners I
prospects.description: This flow sequence focuses on improving mobility in the hips. It’s the perfect active recovery routine to practice on your day off, energize you first thing in the morning, or flow-through before your run. To get the most out of this session, try to synchronize your breathing and movement while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Balance and Core Control for Runners
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve your balance and core control, indispensable skills for all runners. We strengthen the abs, obliques, and hips, with a focus on moving slowly with control, dynamically between the postures.

prospects.name: Upper Body Strength
prospects.description: Those things you use to type and lift up your coffee cup? Yeah, those could be a bit stronger. So it's time to build strength in your upper body—in the hands, wrists, arms, shoulders, chest, and core. It is based around Sun Salutation, a yoga sequence that builds strength, increases power, and improves endurance.

prospects.name: Core Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the spine, ribs and pelvis; strengthen the deep abdominals, obliques and lower back; and activate the glutes to improve balance, help to prevent and alleviate lower back pain and enhance athletic performance. It's a great session to do in the morning or pre-workout.

prospects.name: Hip and Pelvis Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we strengthen the hips through their full range of motion and stabilize the pelvis to improve balance and reduce your risk of knee, IT band, and lower back injury. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Mobilize and Activate
prospects.description: Get out of your habitual movement patterns and get ready to take on the day with this activation session. You'll flow through a series of standing yoga poses to simultaneously challenge your strength, flexibility, and range of motion, leaving you feeling energized.

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners I
prospects.description: The power to to put watts to the pedals comes not just from your legs, but from your core. When your core is strong and stable, you can generate more power, more efficiently. You'll also suffer less back pain. With those goals in mind, this sequence strengthens the abs, obliques, and lower back.

prospects.name: Hamstring & Hip Release
prospects.description:
This hip-opening sequence is particularly effective for stretching the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads. It's ideal for practicing after a workout or in the evening to increase flexibility and loosen up the hips.

​

The objectives are to stretch the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads; open up the hips; and trigger a parasympathetic nervous system response.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Child’s Pose
- Downward Dog
- Runners Lunge
- Side Lunge
- Lizard
- Frog
- Hip Circles
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe 1 + 2
- Knees-To-Chest

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Spinal Flexibility
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence focuses on enhancing spinal flexibility by moving the spine through flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral flexion. It targets the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes. This routine is excellent for increasing range of motion and reducing stiffness throughout the body. It can be practiced in the morning to help wake up or directly after a workout to prevent pain and stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase spine and shoulder mobility, stretch the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes, and reduce overall stiffness.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Sun Salutation
- Standing Sidebends
- Cat–Cow
- One-Handed Tiger
- Puppy + Twisted Puppy
- Seated Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Hamstrings and TFL for Runners
prospects.description: This therapeutic session is designed to strengthen and stretch the back of your thighs and outside hips to improve mobility and ensure proper function. It can help to alleviate lower back pain and can be practiced in the morning, evening, or directly after training.

prospects.name: Classic Yoga Flow
prospects.description:
This classic, hip-focused sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and groin, and strengthening the quads and hips. As you become familiar with the routine, you can work on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to breathe in and out through your nose throughout. It is an excellent practice for the morning to sharpen your focus or directly after a workout to help prevent muscle stiffness.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, strengthen the hips and quads, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and groin, and practice synchronizing breath and movement.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- High Lunge (+ Twist)
- Downward Dog
- Warrior 2
- Triangle
- Squat
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Side Bends
prospects.description: If you're pushing yourself hard, it's likely you're getting stiff and sore all over. Side bends are one of my favorite ways to deal with general soreness. They're also perfect for cyclists who typically suffer from poor lateral flexibility.

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Happy Baby
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Off Balance
prospects.description:
This balance sequence starts with engaging one-legged standing postures that strengthen the feet, ankles, hips, and glutes, and concludes with a challenging Side Plank series aimed at strengthening the hips, abs, and obliques. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives are to improve balance, proprioception, and body awareness; strengthen the feet, ankles, hips, glutes, core, arms, and shoulders; enhance focus and concentration; and practice diaphragmatic, nasal breathing.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Tiptoes
- Sidebending-Tree
- Knee Hugs
- Dancer
- Side Plank Variations
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners II
prospects.description: Building on the gains you've achieved after doing the Core Strengtheners exercises several times, this session further strengthens the core.

prospects.name: Post-Run Stretch
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to keep you strong, supple, and always in the game. It’s a simple and easy series of poses that slowly and carefully allows you to release tension in the primary muscles of the lower body, including the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, glutes, piriformis, and lower back.

prospects.name: One Hour Total Body Stretch
prospects.description:
This one-hour total body stretch includes 25 poses, starting with the upper body to stretch the neck, shoulders, chest, and forearms, then progressing to the lower back, glutes, groin, hip flexors, quads, hamstrings, calves, and ankles. It is an excellent routine to practice before bed to release tension in partially-contracted muscles and correct alignment. Deep relaxation into each pose, combined with nasal breathing and extended exhalations, enhances the stretch's intensity.

​

The objectives are to deeply relax the body and mind, loosen the neck and shoulders, increase spinal mobility, open up the hips (including the hip flexors, groin, glutes, and piriformis), stretch the calves and hamstrings, improve the range of motion in the feet and ankles, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

​

**Poses:**

- Thunderbolt
- Puppy + Reverse Prayer
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Half Monkey
- Side Lunge
- Half-Twisted Lizard
- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Child
- Bridge
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe A + B
- Groin Stretch
- Quad Stretch
- Reclining Spinal Eagle Twist
- Knees-To-Chest
- Reclining Butterfly

prospects.name: Hips and Hamstrings
prospects.description: This routine is designed to open up the hips—the hip flexors, rotators, and glutes—and stretch the hamstrings. The session guides you through a series of lunges and finishes with Lizard and Pigeon pose. You can practice it in the morning, before or after a ride. Experiment to see what works best for you.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Full Body Mobility
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve the range of motion throughout the body, focusing on the spine, shoulders, and hips. It combines twists, side bends, and balance poses to enhance total body flexibility and agility.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Hip Mobility Flow for Runners II
prospects.description: In this flow sequence, we activate the muscles in both the upper and lower leg, move into stretches for the hip flexors and groin and finish with a deep hamstring stretch. You can practice this sequence in the morning, before your run, or on your day off as active recovery.

prospects.name: Abs & Obliques
prospects.description:
This challenging core stability workout is designed to strengthen the abs, obliques, and lower back. It engages all three planes of motion—sagittal (planks), frontal (side planks), and transverse (poses with rotation)—to achieve maximum core strength and stability. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or as a standalone session.

​

The primary objective is to strengthen the core, including the abs, obliques, and lower back.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Plank
- Locust
- Spider Planks
- Child’s Pose
- Side Plank Variations
- Boat Variations
- Leg Raises
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Balance and Agility
prospects.description: Maintaining effective cycling form when you're under pressure requires substantial balance, coordination, agility, and core strength. This series will develop those capabilities so you can put down the power when it really matters.

prospects.name: Stretch Out Your Legs
prospects.description:
This cool-down stretch is designed to release tension in the legs and hips, targeting the glutes, piriformis, calves, hamstrings, groin, quads, TFL, and lower back. It's an ideal routine for athletes to practice directly after a workout or in the evening before bed.

​

The objectives include stretching the glutes, piriformis, hamstrings, calves, groin, quads, and TFL, releasing tension in the lower back, and helping the body transition into the parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise, potentially alleviating lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Reclining Groin Stretch
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Spinal Twist (Eagle Variation)

prospects.name: Balance & Mobility
prospects.description:
This balance sequence is excellent for training balance and proprioception, while also improving overall mobility, particularly in the spine and hips. It provides a challenging workout for the quads and glutes, making it a great choice for the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives include improving balance, proprioception, and body awareness; strengthening the knees, quads, and glutes; opening up the hips and chest; enhancing mobility in the spine; boosting focus and concentration; and practicing diaphragmatic, nasal breathing.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- High Lunge with Chest Opener
- Flying Lunge
- Warrior 3 with Chest Opener
- Chair Pose Twists
- Revolved Side Angle
- Awkward Pose
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Off Balance
prospects.description:
This balance sequence starts with engaging one-legged standing postures that strengthen the feet, ankles, hips, and glutes, and concludes with a challenging Side Plank series aimed at strengthening the hips, abs, and obliques. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives are to improve balance, proprioception, and body awareness; strengthen the feet, ankles, hips, glutes, core, arms, and shoulders; enhance focus and concentration; and practice diaphragmatic, nasal breathing.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Tiptoes
- Sidebending-Tree
- Knee Hugs
- Dancer
- Side Plank Variations
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Hip Openers
prospects.description: Seeing gains from the _Hip Openers_ session? This series will build on those gains, further loosening overworked and inflexible muscles in and around the hip joints.

prospects.name: Core Stability II for Runners
prospects.description: This simple core strength sequence has all your bases covered. We strengthen the deep core stabilizers, superficial abs, obliques, and lower back. It’s a great one to do before your run to activate key muscle groups, in the morning to set you up for the day, or after an easy run.

prospects.name: Yoga for Travel
prospects.description: If you're traveling and will be off your bike for some time, you might feel that all is lost. But we've created a routine for travelers to keep you balanced, loose, and strong. Do this daily while on the road so you'll be in top condition when you can get back home.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 01
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that develops your overall coordination and control._

​

As the first session in this progression, we introduce you to an integrated sequence of athletic movements. This mix may feel different and challenging..maybe even fun! Embrace it!

​

Please take your time, especially in this initial session. Start and stop the video to rewatch the demonstrations, if necessary, to ensure you understand the movement and grasp the range of motion. Finally, for the exercises that include a balance component, it will be ideal to keep your gaze fixed on a still object, not your screen.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Backbend w/ Arms overhead
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Around the clock Heel & Toe Taps
- Alternating-Step Under
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Low Skip In Place
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Tip Toe Walk
- Deep Squat w/Arms Crossed
- Drop to Squat & Hold - Dbl. Leg
- Hop to Opposite Leg w/Hold
- Toe Touch

prospects.name: Full Body 02
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

In this session, we introduce you to a few more foundational moves. Learn them well as you’ll see them throughout the program as you progress. And as you progress, we'll continue to add more difficult variations on these basics - so develop good habits now for easy mastery down the road.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Forward Lunge
- Lateral Lunge with Extended Hands
- Hip Hinge
- Squat with Wide Stance
- Plank
- Quadruped with Arm Raise
- Side Plank

prospects.name: Run Focus 1
prospects.description:
The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

In this first routine in the sequence, we'll introduce you to some basic foundational movement patterns that will help improve your running by enhancing lower body and core stability as well as strength. The exercises are simple and the interval durations are short. Utilize the full duration of the session to focus on quality technique using the full range of motion. As the program progresses you'll complete more variations for longer periods, so dial in that good form now.

​

**Included Exercises:**

- Squat Wide Stance Hands Forward
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Squat w/ Hands Behind Head
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Kneeling Hip Drive Hands Up
- Kneeling Hips Side to Side
- Foot Circles
- Backward Lunge Arms on Hips
- Backward Shoulder Rolls
- Deep Squat w/Arms Crossed
- Single Leg Heel Raise
- Hip Hinge-Hands on Head
- Side Lunge to Knee Lift w/ Hold
- Frog Crunch
- Oblique Leg Lifts
- Bird Dog
- Pigeon Stretch
- Runner Stretch

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands to Side
- High Plank
- Plank
- Hip Bridge
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands to Side

prospects.name: Recovery Session B
prospects.description:
This session is designed to keep your body familiar with the basic movements of strength training without adding any extra fatigue to your system. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- High Plank to Pigeon Pose
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Fast Lateral Lunges with Knees Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Side

prospects.name: Run Focus 1
prospects.description:

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

Your posterior chain is responsible for back and hip extension as well as knee flexion. It is vital in maintaining optimal posture during cycling and running in addition to water position in swimming. In this first session, we introduce some basic movements that focus on the activation and stabilization of posterior chain muscles. These moves include a combination of eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding) contractions. They provide your body with the foundation for more demanding moves to come. This is also a good session to come back to if you feel like you could use a quick posterior chain activation or tune-up.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Side bend w/ Arms Overhead
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Kneeling Hip Extension
- Quadruped w/ Cervical Extension
- Quadruped Chin Tucks
- Double Leg Hip Bridge
- High Plank w/ Alt. Arm Raise
- High Plank w/ Hip Abduction + Tap
- 45° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Lat Press on Wall-Reps
- 90° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Overhead Reverse Fly w/ Hold
- KickBacks from Toes
- Hamstring Hip Bridge
- Marching Hip Bridge
- Back Extension w/ opposite arm & leg raise
- Downward Dog
- Pigeon Stretch

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 01
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that develops your overall coordination and control._

​

As the first session in this progression, we introduce you to an integrated sequence of athletic movements. This mix may feel different and challenging..maybe even fun! Embrace it!

​

Please take your time, especially in this initial session. Start and stop the video to rewatch the demonstrations, if necessary, to ensure you understand the movement and grasp the range of motion. Finally, for the exercises that include a balance component, it will be ideal to keep your gaze fixed on a still object, not your screen.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Backbend w/ Arms overhead

- Around the clock Heel & Toe Taps
- Alternating-Step Under
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Low Skip In Place
- Single leg Hip Hinge

prospects.name: Full Body 04
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time. We recommend you warm up before starting this routine._

​

By now, you should be well on your way to mastering the foundation moves with perfect form. So let’s mix things up a bit and add further variations in order to keep challenging you. We'll also increase the duration of a few sets since your endurance has increased already.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

In this routine, we’re going to throw in a few moves you haven’t seen yet to complete the foundational moves in the Full Body series. You’ll also find some new, subtle variations to the exercises you know well. While the differences seem small, the unique demands will speed up your adaptation phase.

These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

prospects.name: Run Focus 2
prospects.description:
The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

In this second session, we'll build on the foundational movement patterns that you mastered in the previous routine. Run Focus 2 also includes new progressions to increase the number of activated muscle groups as well as some hopping moves to help challenge your hip and ankle stability.

​

**Included Exercises:**

- Squat Wide Stance Hands Forward

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 02
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

Now that you’ve completed Level 1, it’s time to add a layer of neuromuscular coordination. This sequence includes balance, unilateral drills, lower body strength, and jumping exercises - and combinations of those. You’ll even complete integrated exercises which involve single-leg challenges in various directions. Focus on controlled deliberate movements and solid landings to master this session.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Full Body 06
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

At this level, we can begin to throw in more upper body and core work compared to previous Full Body sessions. The goal is not to develop big muscles in your arms and chest, but to build basic functional strength to help you improve stability and become a more well-rounded athlete.

​

This extra work is derived from more difficult variations of the foundation moves. While the added upper-body component will decrease the number of reps you can complete in a set, your primary goal remains to nail perfect form. Even though you've been at this for several weeks your nervous system is still learning these movement patterns. Keep focusing on completing the exercise correctly rather than moving quickly.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

Your posterior chain is responsible for back and hip extension as well as knee flexion. It is vital in maintaining optimal posture during cycling and running in addition to water position in swimming. In this first session, we introduce some basic movements that focus on the activation and stabilization of posterior chain muscles. These moves include a combination of eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding) contractions. They provide your body with the foundation for more demanding moves to come. This is also a good session to come back to if you feel like you could use a quick posterior chain activation or tune-up.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Side bend w/ Arms Overhead
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Kneeling Hip Extension
- Quadruped w/ Cervical Extension
- Quadruped Chin Tucks
- Double Leg Hip Bridge
- High Plank w/ Alt. Arm Raise
- High Plank w/ Hip Abduction + Tap
- 45° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Lat Press on Wall-Reps
- 90° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Overhead Reverse Fly w/ Hold
- KickBacks from Toes
- Hamstring Hip Bridge
- Marching Hip Bridge
- Back Extension w/ opposite arm & leg raise
- Downward Dog
- Pigeon Stretch

prospects.name: Upper Body Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

As the first session in this series, we’re going to introduce you to some basic upper body movements. This sequence will be beneficial for endurance sports where you need some upper body strength and improved posture, such as swimming, cycling (especially MTB and Cyclocross), and running. To help ensure overall strength, this routine incorporates some core muscle exercises and you may find some portions of the sequence difficult. No problem! Take your time to understand the movement. Pause the video if you need to and embrace the process of mastering new exercises.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Overhead Shoulder Rolls
- Standing T-Spine Rotations
- Lat Press with a Hold
- Hip Hinges on the Wall
- 45 Degree Reverse Fly
- Wide Pushups
- Quadruped Pull-In with Hold
- Quadruped Push-Out with Hold
- Low Plank with Scapular Presses
- Low Side Plank with Toe Taps
- High Plank with Alternate Arm Raise
- Back Extensions
- Cervical Extensions
- Chin Tucks from a Quadruped Position
- Quadruped T-Spine Rotations
- Oblique Leg Lifts
- Side-Lying T-Spine Arcs

prospects.name: Full Body 07
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

At this point, you’ve mastered the form and balance demands of the basic foundational moves. We’re kicking the duration and intensity up a notch here. Variations on these exercises will become more and more difficult and any bad habits will become amplified - so keep paying attention to getting that form right under this increased workload.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 03
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

Ready for the third workout in the Dynamic Focus series? All athletes, including competitors in endurance sports, benefit from training that better helps you react to external factors in varying directions; people, wind, waves, inclines, and surfaces. This sequence will prime you for these variables with varying tempos. With a combination of exercises that integrate three-dimensional motion this session will keep your neuromuscular system primed and ready for anything, no matter what type of rubber you’re on.

Welcome to the second session in this series. We’re going to continue the focus on increasing strength in the chest, back, shoulders and arms. Many of the exercises will be familiar from Level 1, but you’ll likely find it a bit more challenging. That’s because we’ve made the durations a bit longer and the moves a little more complex. The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

Run Focus 3 adds an additional layer of difficulty to the foundational moves, with dynamic movements and sequences that help build balance and stability. There are also more integrated variations that incorporate the upper body for full-body activation. This session maintains the strong focus on glute and thigh musculature, as well as enhancing stability at the ankle and hip, and ensuring the engagement of the three-dimensional core.

The fourth sequence in this Dynamic Focus series challenges your neuromuscular coordination with longer intervals. Integrated exercises with balance, unilateral drills, lower body strength, and jumping are all present. With a focus on stability toward the second half of the session, you’ll be forced to control your motion when tired. Now that you’ve completed Level 1, it’s time to add a layer of neuromuscular coordination. prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

As the first session in this series, we’re going to introduce you to some basic upper body movements. This sequence will be beneficial for endurance sports where you need some upper body strength and improved posture, such as swimming, cycling (especially MTB and Cyclocross), and running. To help ensure overall strength, this routine incorporates some core muscle exercises and you may find some portions of the sequence difficult. No problem! Take your time to understand the movement. Pause the video if you need to and embrace the process of mastering new exercises.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Recovery Session B
prospects.description:
This session is designed to keep your body familiar with the basic movements of strength training without adding any extra fatigue to your system. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- High Plank to Pigeon Pose
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Fast Lateral Lunges with Knees Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Side

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

prospects.description: Diaphragmatic Breathing is a calming exercise that encourages you to breathe deeply into your abdomen. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.

With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

This session has a greater focus on your upper body and core work to truly integrate your strength training. The second session in this series focuses on activating and strengthening key structural stability muscles and developing optimal tension throughout the body. ​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

Well done getting to this point! prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 04
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

The fourth sequence in this Dynamic Focus series challenges your neuromuscular coordination with longer intervals. Integrated exercises with balance, unilateral drills, lower body strength, and jumping are all present. With a focus on stability toward the second half of the session, you’ll be forced to control your motion when tired. Your concentration and endurance will be pushed to maintain quality execution the entire time.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Run Focus 4
prospects.description:
The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

In Run Focus 4 you'll complete the foundational moves with longer, more challenging combinations to help improve your dynamic stability and muscular endurance. We also added strength exercises that incorporate a mobility component, particularly at the hips. Since you've already mastered the basics, focus on completing every repetition with perfect form, full range of motion, and controlled timing.

​

**Included Exercises:**

- Squat Wide Stance Hands Forward
- Single-Leg Hip Hinge w/ Rotation

prospects.name: Upper Body Focus 02
prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

Welcome to the second session in this series. We’re going to continue the focus on increasing strength in the chest, back, shoulders and arms. Many of the exercises will be familiar from Level 1, but you’ll likely find it a bit more challenging. That’s because we’ve made the durations a bit longer and the moves a little more complex. Challenge yourself to maintain quality repetitions throughout the sequence and strive for a full range of motion.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included**

- Overhead Shoulder Rolls w/ Stick

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

Like the Previous Posterior Chain sessions, Level 3 targets the muscles of the back side of your body. However, this routine has a greater concentration on upper back and posterior shoulder strength than the earlier sessions. This more advanced combination of movements will challenge your stability and strength endurance. If you find yourself struggling with some of the moves late in the session it's ok to pause the video and take a breath. Your form is the most important thing here, so don’t push through and get sloppy.

​

​

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

Your posterior chain is responsible for back and hip extension as well as knee flexion. It is vital in maintaining optimal posture during cycling and running in addition to water position in swimming. In this first session, we introduce some basic movements that focus on the activation and stabilization of posterior chain muscles. These moves include a combination of eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding) contractions. They provide your body with the foundation for more demanding moves to come. This is also a good session to come back to if you feel like you could use a quick posterior chain activation or tune-up.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

As the first session in this series, we’re going to introduce you to some basic upper body movements. This sequence will be beneficial for endurance sports where you need some upper body strength and improved posture, such as swimming, cycling (especially MTB and Cyclocross), and running. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

In Run Focus 4 you'll complete the foundational moves with longer, more challenging combinations to help improve your dynamic stability and muscular endurance. We also added strength exercises that incorporate a mobility component, particularly at the hips. Since you've already mastered the basics, focus on completing every repetition with perfect form, full range of motion, and controlled timing.

​

prospects.name: Full Body 16
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

By this point, you’re no longer struggling with single-leg balance and stability, which allows us to really focus on building raw muscular endurance in your lower body. Additionally, this routine will place greater demands on your upper body and core than any previous session has. Not only do you have 10+ minutes dedicated to the muscles above your hips, but the progression of High Planks and High Side Planks means that even the “core-work” moves have a difficult upper-body component. prospects.name: Run Focus 5
prospects.description:
The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

This final session in the series is designed to target all the components critical for success in running: strength, endurance, stability, mobility, and flexibility. This session targets common areas of weakness for runners caused by the repetitive motion that occurs in a single plane when running. You should now have the confidence to perform each repetition with quality for the entire interval duration. Focus, push through the temporary fatigue, and you'll come out of the session stronger, more stable, and more flexible.

prospects.name: Upper Body Focus 04
prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

Ready to work hard? Level 4 will not disappoint in terms of overloading your chest, back, shoulders, arms, and core. Among other challenges, this workout includes two new tempo repetitions and work with resistance bands. The tempo training increases muscle activity as you react to sudden starts and stops while the resistance bands demand consistent focus with tension in all directions. And if you fall in love with any of these fantastic exercises, don’t worry -- you’re quite likely to see them again before the routine is over.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head

- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

prospects.name: Upper Body Focus 05
prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

The final workout in the Upper Body series will not disappoint. Now is your time to show you can dominate the exercises for longer durations while maintaining quality repetitions. The primary components of strength training for the chest, back, shoulders, arms, and core are all present. There is plenty of mobility work for the complex upper body joints, too. Swimmers, cyclists, runners, and multisport athletes will all benefit from training at this level.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

++**Exercises Included:**++

- Overhead Shoulder Rolls w/ Stick

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 05
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

You’ve made it - the highest level in the Posterior Chain series. Here, we continue to load the back side of the body but also add in movements that require integration with other areas. Your muscular endurance will be challenged with external loads from bands, longer sets, and combination movements. To top it off, we even challenge your nervous system with tempo changes and unilateral exercises that require mental focus and muscular control.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Recoil Hamstring Stretch

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 08
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

The final sequence in the Dynamic Focus series is the ultimate (!) challenge. It includes the classic exercises of balance, unilateral drills, lower body strength, and jumping; both independently and integrated. These movements, which incorporate stability, power, and coordination applications, will bring out the best athlete in you- improving your endurance, strength, and sprinting ability. Go for it!

​

prospects.name: Run Focus 5
prospects.description:
The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

This final session in the series is designed to target all the components critical for success in running: strength, endurance, stability, mobility, and flexibility. This session targets common areas of weakness for runners caused by the repetitive motion that occurs in a single plane when running. You should now have the confidence to perform each repetition with quality for the entire interval duration. Focus, push through the temporary fatigue, and you'll come out of the session stronger, more stable, and more flexible.

​

**Included Exercises:**

- Squat Wide Stance Hands Forward
- Single-Leg Hip Hinge w/ Rotation
- Squat w/ Hands Behind Head
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Standing Hip Drive Hands Up
- Step Overs
- Alternating-Step Under
- Foot Circles
- Single-Leg Hip Bridge w/ Rotation
- Fire Hydrant
- Single-Leg squat to press
- Backward Shoulder Rolls
- Single-Leg Heel Raise
- Tempo Squat
- Tempo Split stance Hip Hinge
- Side Lunge w/ Knee Lift & Opposite Arm Press
- Inchworm
- Single-Leg Hop to Hold
- Downward Dog
- Frog Crunch
- High Side Plank Hold
- Bicycle Crunch
- High Plank w/ Opposite Arm & Leg Raise
- Pigeon Stretch
- Runner Stretch

prospects.name: Upper Body Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

As the first session in this series, we’re going to introduce you to some basic upper body movements. This sequence will be beneficial for endurance sports where you need some upper body strength and improved posture, such as swimming, cycling (especially MTB and Cyclocross), and running. To help ensure overall strength, this routine incorporates some core muscle exercises and you may find some portions of the sequence difficult. No problem! Take your time to understand the movement. Pause the video if you need to and embrace the process of mastering new exercises.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Standing T-Spine Rotations

prospects.name: Recovery Session B
prospects.description:
This session is designed to keep your body familiar with the basic movements of strength training without adding any extra fatigue to your system. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- High Plank to Pigeon Pose
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Fast Lateral Lunges with Knees Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Side

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands to Side
- High Plank
- Plank
- Hip Bridge
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands to Side

prospects.name: Breathing More Deeply
prospects.description: Diaphragmatic Breathing is a calming exercise that encourages you to breathe deeply into your abdomen. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.
